Fig. 1 Schematic diagram of substrate molecule diffusing toward active sites through pore channel. Fig. 2 Effect of reaction time on the catalytic performance of Ni@SiO2–0.2 in the reductive amination of HMF. Reaction conditions: 1 mmol HMF, 5 g NH3·H2O (25 wt%), temperature 170 ℃, 2 MPa H2, substrate: catalyst = 5:1 (mass ratio). Fig. 3 Effect of reaction temperature on the catalytic performance of Ni@SiO2–0.2 in the reductive amination of HMF. Conditions: 1 mmol HMF, 5 g NH3·H2O (25 wt%), time 14 h, 2 MPa H2, substrate: catalyst = 5:1 (mass ratio). Fig. 4 Effect of HMF to catalyst mass ratio on the reductive amination of HMF to BAF over catalyst Ni@SiO2–0.2. Reaction conditions: 1 mmol HMF, 5 g NH3·H2O (25 wt%), temperature 160 ℃, time 14 h, 2 MPa H2. Fig. 5 Effect of H2 pressure on the catalytic performance of Ni@SiO2–0.2 in the reductive amination of HMF. Reaction conditions: 1 mmol HMF, 5 g NH3·H2O (25 wt%), temperature 160 ℃, time 14 h, substrate: catalyst = 20:1 (mass ratio). Fig. 6 Recycle test of Ni@SiO2–0.2 in the reductive amination of HMF to BAF. Reaction conditions: 1 mmol HMF, substrate: catalyst = 50:1, 5 mL NH3·H2O (25 wt%), temperature 160 °C, 2 MPa H2, reaction time 14 h. Fig. 7 The XRD patterns of the samples of NiO NPs, NiO@SiO2–0.2, fresh and used Ni@SiO2–0.2 catalyst. Fig. 8 XPS spectra of the samples of fresh Ni NPs, fresh and used Ni@SiO2–0.2 catalyst. School of Chemical Engineering and Technology Hebei University of Technology Tianjin 300131 China Graphical abstract 2,5-Bis(aminomethyl)furan (BAF) is a diamine that is expected to have extensive applications in organic synthesis, medicine and polymer materials such as polyamides and polyimides. BAF can be prepared by one-step reductive amination of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), one of the platform compounds for the added-valueconversion of biomass. Due to its complex structure, the one-step catalytically reductive amination of HMF to BAF in high yield is still a challenging issue. Herein, a core–shell structured catalyst (Ni@SiO2–0.2) was developed for this reaction, and the yield of BAF reached up to 99 % with aqueous ammonia as both ammonia source and solvent due to an isolation effect of the SiO2 shell. The isolation effect can prevent direct hydrogenation of HMF and self-coupling of BAF, thereby enhancing the selectivity of the reductive amination of HMF to BAF. In addition, the textural structure, acidity and acidic sites of the SiO2 shell can be tuned by adjusting the amount of TEOS during the catalyst preparation process, thus optimizing the performance of the catalyst. The characterization results also revealed that the Ni nanoparticles in the catalyst are uniformly dispersed and encapsulated within the SiO2 shell, which can decrease the charge density on the Ni surface and enhance the adsorption of ammonia and intermediates on the Ni surface, thus enhancing the catalytic activity of the catalyst. Keywords One-step reductive amination Core-shell structure Ni@SiO2 catalyst 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural 2,5-Bis(aminomethyl)furan Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Diamines play a crucial role in organic synthesis and are also widely utilized as monomers or intermediates in the production of polymers, pharmaceuticals, dyes, and detergents [1,2]. Currently, the production of diamines heavily relies on fossil resources [3,4], which is faced with challenges such as resource depletion and worsening environmental pollution. By transitioning to renewable biomass-based resources, the production of diamines not only reduces our dependence on fossil resources but also expands the range of polymer materials and enhances the quality of related products, while being environmentally friendly [5,6]. However, the study on the conversion of biomass-derived molecules into valuable primary amines is still in its early stages. 2,5-Bis(aminomethyl)furan (BAF) is a diamine possessing large potential applications in organic synthesis as well as medicine, which can be prepared by catalytic amination of biomass derived 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF). Its structural symmetry and the presence of a more active amino group on the furan ring make it suitable for the production of polyamides and polyimides, too [7,8]. The HMF derived polymer materials generally exhibit high mechanical strength and a low thermal expansion coefficient, making them comparable to traditional petrochemical-based products, thereby endowing them with significant applications in various industries including automobiles, aerospace, electrical and electronics, and construction. Besides, BAF can also serve as a hardener for epoxy resins. Especially, BAF is a precursor for the manufacture of 2,5-bis(aminomethyl)tetrahydrofuran (THBAF) that also finds important applications in the aforementioned fields [9,10]. The catalytic amination of HMF to BAF over various homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts has been reported [11]. For instance, Li et al. [12] developed a two-step process to convert HMF to BAF, consisting of oxidation of HMF to 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF) and catalytically reductive of DFF in the presence of NH3 and H2 over Raney Ni. However, the yield of BAF was only 42.6 % under optimized reaction conditions. Michikazu Hara et al. [13] reported another two-step process for the synthesis of BAF from HMF over a Ru/Nb2O5 catalyst in combination with a Ru complex system. Firstly, HMF was hydrogenated to AMAF over Ru/Nb2O5 in a yield of 96 %. Then, AMAF underwent amination with [Ru(CO)ClH(PPh3)3]/Xantphos as a homogeneous catalyst system via borrowing‐hydrogen methodology to give BAF quantitatively. The excessively expensive catalyst is the fatal weakness of this process. Shi et al. [14] reported a two-stage heating, one-pot method to convert HMF to BAF over a bifunctional CuNiAlOx catalyst, which are conducting the reductive amination of aldehyde moiety at 90 ℃, then the amination of alcohol moiety at 210 ℃ in 1,4-dioxane. Only in the presence of a significant amount of alkaline as additives the conversion of HMF was 99 % and the yield of BAF reached 85.9 %. Overall, most of the protocols or catalytic systems suffer from the disadvantages of organic solvent usage [12,15,16], expensive reactants [13,17], and multiple steps [10,14,18,19]. In principle, the one-step catalytically reductive amination of HMF with ammonia using hydrogen as reductant is the most direct process to obtain BAF. Therefore, several catalysts or catalytic systems have been developed for this transformation under mild conditions, but very low yield of BAF and short lifetime of catalysts were generally observed [12,15]. Therefore, the one-step catalytically reductive amination of HMF to BAF is still a challenging task. In view of the structure of HMF, the low yield of BAF could be mainly ascribed to the direct hydrogen of HMF, being a competitive reaction with catalytic amination under the reaction conditions. In addition, the presence of unsaturated bonds including C=C and C=O in the HMF structure makes it more prone to oligomerization under the reaction conditions, which is another significant factor contributing to the low selectivity of BAF [18]. Obviously, the key to solve the above problems is to design catalysts that can prevent direct hydrogenation and oligomerization of HMF. Core-shell catalysts have gained significant attention in catalytic reactions due to their unique structural properties [20–22]. These catalysts exhibit improved activity and selectivity compared to traditional catalysts by leveraging the advantages of both the core and shell components. They demonstrate metal-support mutual synergistic effects, molecular sieve effects, spatial separation effects, and metal stabilizing effects. The curved structure of the core–shell catalyst provides distinct internal and external microenvironments [23]. The metal particles loaded inside the shell undergo more significant charge transfer than those loaded outside the shell [24,25]. The molecular sieve effect can be achieved through the adjustable shell thickness and pore structure of the core–shell catalyst. This effect controls the adsorption and diffusion of substrate molecules in the pores by manipulating the shell thickness and internal pore size [26,27]. By adjusting these structural parameters, molecules that are incompatible with the pore size are prevented from entering, while the compatible ones can easily enter, allowing for precise control of catalytic selectivity. Moreover, the molecular sieve effect also influences reaction kinetics, thereby impacting the overall reaction rate [28–31]. Another important effect is the spatial separation effect, which can be utilized in cascade reactions to simplify complex operations such as separation, purification, and concentration of intermediates [32,33]. By cleverly designing core–shell structural parameters such as shell thickness, pore size, and metal position, substrate molecules can be directed to specific positions within the shell. This promotes rapid conversion of intermediates, suppresses the formation of by-products, and enhances the selectivity and efficiency of the desired product. Long-lasting catalytic stability is a crucial requirement for achieving satisfactory catalytic performance. In metal-supported catalysts, deactivation such as poisoning, sintering, and leaching of metal particles are commonly observed [34–38]. However, by encapsulating metal particles in a core–shell structure, a metal stabilizing effect can be achieved, effectively inhibiting the aforementioned deactivation mechanisms and ensuring long-lasting catalytic stability. Liu et al. [38] successfully developed a Cu-SSZ-13@Ce0.75Zr0.25O2 core–shell catalyst using a hydrothermal method. The catalyst was subjected to treatment with H2O, SO2, and K+ with excellent tolerance. The Ce0.75Zr0.25O2 shell served as a sacrificial site, effectively capturing SO2 and forming sulfate, and subsequently capturing K+. Furthermore, the Ce0.75Zr0.25O2 shell provided additional Brønsted acid sites and enhanced the adsorption and activation of NOx. Herein, a core–shell structured catalyst (Ni@SiO2–0.2) was developed for the one-step catalytically reductive amination of HMF to BAF in high selectivity. The pore size and thickness of the SiO2 shell was optimized by adjusting the molar ratio of Si to Ni during the preparation of the catalysts, which led to the catalyst Ni@SiO2–0.2 with excellent catalytic performance owing to the isolation effect of the SiO2 shell to inhibit direct hydrogenation, self-coupling of BAF and oligomerization of HMF. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of core–shell structured catalysts Catalyst precursor was obtained by dispersing metal oxides through ultrasound, followed by hydrolysis of tetraethoxysilane (TEOS) in ammonia to form catalyst precursor. The precursor was then subjected to calcination and reduction to obtain the catalyst. The detailed processes are given in Supporting Information. The nickel-based catalysts were denoted as Ni@SiO2–x, where x represents the molar ratio of Si to Ni in the catalyst. 2.2 Evaluation of the catalytic performance The catalytic evaluation was carried out in a 15 mL stainless steel reactor, with catalyst (0.02 g), HMF (1 mmol) and aqueous ammonia (25 wt%, 5 mL). Before test, the reactor was purged with H2 for five times to replace the residual air, and charged with H2 to 2 MPa. Then the reaction was carried at 160 ℃ under stirring speed of 1500 rpm. After the reaction, the liquid product was separated from the catalyst and subjected to chromatography analysis. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The characterization instruments and processes are provided in the Supporting Information, including Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET), X-ray power diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscope images (TEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), Ammonia Temperature Programmed Desorption (NH3-TPD), and Hydrogen Temperature Programmed Desorption (H2-TPD). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Screening of catalysts For the aim of one-step reductive amination of HMF to BAF in high yield, several catalysts including Raney Ni, metals supported on SiO2 and activated carbon (Ni/SiO2, Ni/C, and Ru/C), and core–shell structured catalysts with different transitional metals (Fe@SiO2, Co@SiO2, Cu@SiO2, and Ni@SiO2) were prepared and evaluated in the reaction under same reaction conditions. The products were determined by LC-MS and GC–MS analysis. The analysis results disclosed that some byproducts including BHF, BHTHF, AMAF, AMTFM, and BAF-N-BAF were generated aside from the target product BAF (Fig. S1, Supporting Information). The selectivity of each product over various catalysts are shown in Table S1 (Supporting Information). In view of the literature [10,13,18], and the organic reaction principles, the formation pathways of the detected products are inferred and shown in Scheme 1 . As disclosed in literature [39–41], the reaction rate of reductive amination of furfural (C=O) is over ten times higher than that of furfuryl alcohol (C–OH) in HMF. Therefore, AMAF is firstly generated via the condensation of carbonyl with ammonia to imine 1 followed by hydrogenation of imine 1. Once the formation of AMAF, the furfuryl alcohol moiety undergoes further amination to give BAF via dehydrogenation, condensation and hydrogenation of imine 2. Meantime, AMAF undergoes direct hydrogenation of furan ring to generate byproduct AMTFM. Besides, the generated BAF can also undergoes self-coupling to form another byproduct BAF-N-BAF [42]. Simultaneously with the reductive amination reaction, the direct hydrogenation of HMF to BHF as a byproduct may take place, and further hydrogenation of BHF to generate byproduct BHTHF. In the case of without exogenous hydrogen introduced (Table 2), BAF may be generated through the second path. Initially, the carbonyl group condenses with ammonia to form imine 1. Subsequently, the alcohol moiety in imine 1 is dehydrogenated to produce imine 2. Then the carbonyl group in imine 2, condenses further with ammonia to afford imine 3. Imine 3 undergoes hydrogenation with the in-situ generated H2 to form imine 4, which is ultimately hydrogenated to BAF. The detailed transformation processes in the reductive amination of HMF over different catalysts will be discussed in the kinetic study section. As shown in Table S1 (Supporting Information), the three Ni-based catalysts without a SiO2 shell (Raney Ni, Ni/SiO2, and Ni/C) showed similar performances, and the main byproducts over the three catalysts were AMAF, BHF, and BAF-N-BAF. Besides, a small amount of BHTHF was generated over Ni/SiO2. For Ru/C with strong hydrogenation activity compared to Ni-based catalysts, the byproducts were BHF, BHTHF, AMTFM, and BAF-N-BAF. The results indicate that excessive hydrogenation activity of a catalyst is unfavorable for the reductive amination of HMF. It can also be concluded that furan ring and BAF can be respectively absorbed on the metal active sites and acidic sites of the catalysts without a SiO2 shell to undergo hydrogenation of furan ring and self-coupling of BAF affording to the corresponding byproducts. For the core–shell structured catalysts (Fe@SiO2, Co@SiO2, Cu@SiO2, and Ni@SiO2), no byproducts BHF, BHTHF, AMTFM, and BAF-N-BAF were formed, indicating the isolation effect of the SiO2 shell to prevent the adsorption of furan ring and BAF on the metal active sites and acidic sites. The Ni@SiO2 showed the best results, and the selectivity of BAF reached 91 % under the HMF conversion of 99 %. The isolation effect can be illustrated as showing in Fig. 1 . The HFM molecule approach the metal core or active center with carbonyl or hydroxyl group through diffusion along the pore channel of the SiO2 shell during the reductive amination reaction, and the appropriate pore structure does not allow the furan ring to approach the active center perpendicular to the radial direction of pore channel. On the other hand, the pore channel cannot accommodate two BAF molecules approaching each other, thus preventing the self-coupling of BAF to BAF-N-BAF. For a core–shell structured catalyst, the thickness of the shell is related to the textural structure of the catalyst, thus has a significant impact on the diffusion of substrates, intermediates, and products, and ultimately affecting the aforementioned isolation effect in the reductive amination of HMF. Therefore, several core–shell structured catalysts with different SiO2 shell thicknesses were prepared by changing the molar ratio of Si to Ni. The catalysis of the catalysts was evaluated and the results are listed in Table 1 . For all the catalysts, the conversion of HMF was 99 %. However, the selectivity of BAF changed with the Si to Ni molar ratio. The catalyst with a Si to Ni molar ratio of 0.2 showed the best result with a BAF selectivity of 91 %. For the catalysts with Si to Ni molar ratios of 0.3, 0.5, and 1, higher than 0.2, the selectivity of BAF decreased with increase in Si to Ni molar ratio. Meanwhile, AMAF as a unique byproduct was observed and its selectivity increased with increase in Si to Ni molar ratio. The results could be ascribed to the small pore diameters and surface areas of the SiO2 shells of the catalysts as shown in Fig. 10 and Table 3 from the N2 adsorption–desorption. The big Si to Ni molar ratio led to small pore diameters and large channel lengths of the SiO2 shell, hindering the diffusion of HMF to and detachment of BAF from the metal core, as well as slowing down the diffusion of AMAF with its hydroxy head to the metal core, thus resulting in the lower selectivity of BAF [43]. For the catalyst with a Si to Ni molar ratio of 0.1, the selectivity of BAF was also lower than that of the catalyst with a Si to Ni molar ratio of 0.2. Besides AMAF, two other byproducts BHF and BAF-N-BAF were also observed. It was confirmed that the excessive low Si to Ni molar ratio led to large pore diameters and short pore channels as shown in Fig. 10 and Table 3, and HMF could diffuse readily to the metal core, reducing the opportunity for condensation of carbonyl with ammonia on the acid sites of SiO2 shell, thus resulting in direct hydrogenation of HMF to BHF. In addition, the large pore volume the SiO2 shell could accommodate two BAF molecules approaching each other to undergo self-coupling over the acidic sites on the inner surfaces of the SiO2 shell, leading to a further decrease in selectivity of BAF. 3.2 Optimization of reaction conditions Next, the reaction parameters in the one-step catalytically reductive amination of HMF were optimized over the Ni@SiO2–0.2 catalyst in order to further improve the selectivity of BAF. First, the effect of reaction time on the reaction was investigated while maintaining the other parameters constant. As shown in Fig. 2 , the conversion of HMF was always 99 % in the screened range of 10–14 h. The selectivity of BAF gradually improved with the increase in reaction time due to the further reductive amination of AMAF to BAF, and reached its maximum of selectivity of 99 % in 14 h, corresponding to a yield of 98 %. Next, the impact of reaction temperature on this reaction was screened and the results are shown in Fig. 3 . As the temperature increased from 150 °C to 170 °C, the selectivity of BAF gradually increased along with the further reductive amination of AMAF to BAF, and reached its maximum of 99 % at 160–170 °C. No byproduct was observed within this temperature range. However, with the temperature increased from 170 ℃ to 190 ℃, the selectivity of BAF decreased sharply due to the hydrogenation of AMAF to AMTFM, and hydrogenation of HEM to BHF and BHTHF, as well as self-coupling of BAF to BAF-N-BAF at excessively high temperature [13]. The occurrence of side reactions might be ascribed to the partial or completely collapse of the SiO2 shell at excessively high temperature, which weakened or even eliminated the isolation effect of the SiO2 shell in the one-step reductive amination of HMF. Therefore, the optimal reaction temperature was determined to be 160 ℃. Then, the influence of catalyst dosage on the reaction was investigated by keeping other parameters constant. As shown in Fig. 4 , the conversion of HMF was always 99 %, but the selectivity of BAF varied with the change of substrate to catalyst mass ratio. When the substrate to catalyst mass ratio was lower than or equal to 10:1, the selectivity of BAF was kept constant of 99 %. However, when the substrate to catalyst mass ratio was higher than 15:1, the selectivity of BAF decreased gradually with increase in substrate to catalyst mass ratio (decrease in catalyst dosage) from 15:1, due to the insufficient conversion of intermediate AMAF to BAF at low catalyst dosage. Therefore, the optimal substrate to catalyst mass ratio was chosen as 10:1. Finally, the effect of H2 pressure on the one-step catalytically reductive amination of HMF was screened by keeping reaction temperature of 160 ℃, reaction time of 14 h and substrate to catalyst mass ratio of 20:1. As indicated in Table 2, the absence of external H2 results in a decreased yield of the BAF, with substantial amounts of imines 3 and 4 as intermediates persisting. The limited availability of H2 in the reactor impeded the conversion of imines 3 and 4 into BAF. As shown in Fig. 5 , with the increase in H2 pressure, the selectivity of BAF increased initially along with the further reductive amination of AMAF to BAF, and reached its maximum of 85 % under 2 MPa. With a further increase in H2 pressure from 2 MPa to 3 MPa, the selectivity of BAF decreased gradually due to the hydrogenation of AMAF to AMTFM, as well as hydrogenation of HEM to BHF and BHTHF at excessive high H2 pressure. No BAF self-coupling to BAF-N-BAF was observed throughout the process. Therefore, the optimal H2 pressure was determined to be 2 MPa. Based on the above experimental results, the optimal reaction parameters for the one-step reductive amination of HMF to BAF over the catalyst Ni@SiO2–0.2 were determined to be a reaction time of 14 h, a reaction temperature of 160 ℃, substrate to catalyst mass ratio of 10:1, hydrogenation pressure of 2 MPa, and using excessive aqueous ammonia as both ammonia source and solvent. Under the optimal parameters, the conversion of HMF reached 99 %, with an BAF selectivity of 99 %, corresponding to a BAF yield of 98 %, which is the best result in the one-step catalytically reductive amination of HMF to BAF up till now. 3.3 Recycle test The reusability of Ni@SiO2–0.2 for the reductive amination of HMF was evaluated under reaction conditions of a reaction temperature of 160 °C, a reaction time of 14 h, and hydrogen pressure of 2 MPa. For the sake of the reliability of the results, the substrate to catalyst mass ratio was chosen as 50:1 to control the yield of BAF about 56.4 % in the first run. After the reaction, the catalyst was readily recovered by a magnet and reused directly after washing with methanol and water. As shown in Fig. 6 , the catalyst was recycled 7 times, and the yield of BAF remained basically unchanged, indicating the excellent stability of the catalyst in catalytic run. 3.4 Catalyst characterization Fig. 7 shows the XRD patterns of the samples of NiO NPs, NiO@SiO2–0.2, fresh and used Ni@SiO2–0.2 catalyst. For the XRD patterns of NiO NPs, NiO@SiO2–0.2, the diffraction peaks representing NiO species are clearly observed [44]. For the sample of fresh Ni@SiO2–0.2, derived from reduction of NiO@SiO2–0.2, strong diffraction peaks at 2θ = 44.5, 51.9, and 76.4° ascribed to (111), (200), and (220) crystal planes of Ni (0), and very weak peaks corresponding to NiO are observed, confirming that Ni mainly exists in the form of Ni (0) in Ni@SiO2–0.2 catalyst [45,46]. No diffraction peaks representing NiO are observed in the XRD patterns of the used sample of Ni@SiO2–0.2, indicating that the residual NiO in the fresh catalyst was completely reduced to Ni (0) during catalytic run. Besides, no sharp diffraction peaks of SiO2 in the XRD patterns is observed, indicating that SiO2 in the shell of the catalysts exists in an amorphous form [47]. Compared to NiO NPs, NiO@SiO2–0.2 shows weak diffraction peaks of Ni2+, which can be attributed to the strong interaction between NiO and SiO2 shell, promoting the dispersion of NiO on the SiO2 shell or the migration of the NiO core into the SiO2 shell to form a core–shell structure [47,48]. The surface composition and chemical states of nickel of the samples of fresh Ni NPs, fresh and used Ni@SiO2–0.2 are analyzed by XPS. As shown in the wide scan XPS spectrum of the Ni@SiO2–0.2 sample (Fig. 8 A) distinct C 1s, O 1s, Ni 2p, and Si 2p peaks are observed obviously confirming the existence of C, O, Si, and Ni elements. No Si 2p peak is observed in the spectrum of Ni NPs sample. The element C comes from CO2 adsorbed on the catalyst surface in the air. The surface content of Ni determined by XPS (Table S2, Supporting Information) is much smaller than those obtained by the analysis of ICP and EDS (Tables S3 and S4, Supporting Information). The comprehensive results disclosed that the buck of Ni is not on the surface of the catalyst, indicating the successful formation of a core–shell structure of the catalyst [49]. The Ni 2p XPS spectra of the samples are shown in Fig. 8B. For the Ni@SiO2–0.2 catalyst, two peaks of Ni0 2p are observed at 870.35 eV (Ni0 2p1/2) and 852.79 eV (Ni0 2p3/2) with two respective satellite peaks at 879.61 eV and 861.01 eV, as well as two peaks appear at 873.96 eV (Ni2+ 2p1/2) and 855.66 eV (Ni2+ 2p3/2) [50,51]. The existence of Ni2+ can be ascribed to the inevitable oxidation of Ni (0) during analytic process due to the strong reducibility of Ni (0). Compared with that of Ni NPs, the Ni0 (2p1/2) of Ni@SiO2–0.2 catalyst shifts from 870.56 eV to 870.35 eV, and the Ni (2p3/2) shifts from 852.96 eV to 852.79 eV, indicating that the coating of SiO2 shell on Ni NPs reduced the binding energy of Ni (0) due to the strong interaction between the metal Ni (0) and SiO2 [43,52], and decreased the charge density on the Ni surface, thus enhancing the adsorption of ammonia and intermediates on the Ni surface, thereby enhancing its catalytic activity. Compared to that of the fresh sample of the Ni@SiO2–0.2 catalyst, the Ni 2p XPS spectrum of the used sample has no intrinsic difference, indicating its excellent stability of the Ni@SiO2–0.2 catalyst during catalytic run as disclosed by recycle test. H2-TPR experiments were conducted to get the reducibility information of NiO species and evaluate the interaction between metallic Ni and SiO2 shell. As depicted in Fig. 9 , the samples of NiO NPs and NiO@SiO2–0.2 respectively exhibit a single H2 reduction peak at 288 ℃ and 306 ℃, corresponding to the reduction of NiO to Ni. Compared with that of NiO NPs catalyst, the reduction peak of NiO of NiO@SiO2 catalyst shifted towards higher temperature (from 288 to 306 ℃) and became wider, indicating the presence of interactions between Ni and SiO2 [53]. In order to gain a better understanding of the textural structures of the catalysts, N2 adsorption–desorption was performed. As shown in Fig. 10 A and Table 3, both the specific surface areas and pore diameters decreased with the increase in Si to Ni molar ratio (increase in TEOS amount during preparation of catalysts). Compared with those of the sample of fresh Ni@SiO2–0.2, both the specific surface area and the pore diameter of the used sample changed slightly, further demonstrating the stability of the Ni@SiO2–0.2 during catalytic run. Furthermore, all the catalyst samples exhibit isotherms of type IV with an H1 hysteresis loop (Fig. 10B), indicating the presence of a mesoporous structure in the catalysts, with a relatively uniform distribution of pores. To better understand the morphology of catalysts, high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) analysis was conducted. In the HR-TEM image of Ni@SiO2–0.2 (Fig. 11 D), the lattice spacing of the nanoparticles is 0.1702 nm and 0.2001 nm, corresponding to Ni (200) and Ni (111), respectively.[54] Fig. 11C is a magnified view of the image of a selected core–shell structure in Fig. 11A. The compositions of the core and the shell are Ni and SiO2, respectively, determined by elemental mapping images (11G, 11H, and 11I). As shown in Fig. 11H and 11I, which are the magnified views of Fig. 11G, the core–shell structure of the Ni@SiO2 catalyst is clearly exhibited, where the green core component is Ni, and the red shell material is SiO2. Fig. S2 shows the TEM image of Ni NPs. Compared Fig. S2 with Fig. 11A and 11B, it can be concluded that exposed metallic nanoparticles of Ni NPs are more prone to aggregation. The SiO2 shell of Ni@SiO2–0.2 or Ni@SiO2–0.5 can prevent Ni cores from aggregation, making the Ni nanoparticles as active components more evenly dispersed and stable than the naked nanoparticles of Ni NPs. From Fig. 11A and 11B, it can be concluded that the thickness of the SiO2 shell increased with an increase in TEOS amount during the preparation of the catalysts. The TEM image of the sample of the used Ni@SiO2–0.2, (Fig. 11E) shows that the particle distribution of that catalyst remains uniform after catalytic run, and no noticeable difference is observed compared to that of the fresh Ni@SiO2–0.2, which is another evidence for the stability of Ni@SiO2–0.2. As shown in Scheme 1, the condensation of carbonyl with ammonia is an elementary reaction in the reductive amination of HMF to BAF. In principle, appropriate amount acidic sites and acidity of a catalyst can facilitate the adsorption of substrates, ammonia, and imine intermediates, thereby enhancing the catalytic amination of carbonyl compounds. Excessive acidity can hinder the condensation reaction between carbonyl and NH3, inhibit desorption of ammonia and products, and lead to an increase in self-coupling of amines and oligomerization reactions [55,56]. The surface acidities of the catalysts were determined by NH3-TPD method. Fig. 12 shows the NH3-TPD curves of the Ni@SiO2–x catalysts. The catalysts exhibit two main NH3 desorption peaks within the temperature range of 50–700 °C, corresponding to the NH3 adsorbed on the weak acid sites and strong acid sites on the catalyst surfaces. As shown in Fig. 12, the desorption temperature of ammonia at the strong acid sites increased with the increase in SiO2 to Ni molar ratio, as well as the peak area corresponding to the strong acid content. Table 4 shows the NH3 adsorption capacity of the catalyst. Among all the tested Ni@SiO2–x catalysts, the Ni@SiO2–0.2 catalyst has moderate acid strength and suitable amount of acid sites, which facilitates the adsorption and desorption of reaction reactants, intermediates and BAF in the condensation step, thereby positively influencing the overall catalytic reaction to afford BAF with the highest selectivity. The Ni@SiO2–0.1 catalyst has the lowest weak acidity and acid sites, consequently, showed poor catalytic activity in the reaction. However, the Ni@SiO2–0.3 and Ni@SiO2–0.5 catalysts have excessively strong acidity and acid sites, hindering the desorption of NH3, AMAF, and BAF, thus resulting in poor catalytic performances of the catalysts in the reaction, too. 3.5 Reaction kinetic profiles According to literature, the control step of the HMF reductive amination should be the dehydrogenation of the alcohol (AMAF) to the aldehyde AFCA. In order to gain a better understanding of this process, we conducted a study on the reaction kinetics over the catalysts, and the results are shown in Fig. 13 . For the catalysts Ni/SiO2 and Ni@SiO2–0.1 (Fig. 13Aand 13C), the C=O in HMF quickly condenses with NH3 to form imine 1, which is then hydrogenated to AMAF. Once AMAF is formed, the furfuryl alcohol moiety undergoes a slow dehydrogenation process to form AFCA. Subsequently, the C=O in AFCA condenses with ammonia to generate imine 4, which undergoes hydrogenation to give BAF. Simultaneously, the furan ring in AMAF is directly hydrogenated to the by-product AMTFM. Additionally, the generated BAF can undergo self-coupling to produce another by-product BAF-N-BAF. Furthermore, during the reductive amination reaction, HMF can be directly hydrogenated to the by-product BHF, which can further undergo hydrogenation to form BHTHF. In the case of Ni@SiO2–0.1 as a catalyst, the presence of the SiO2 shell provides acidic sites to enhance the condensation of C=O with NH3, thereby inhibiting the direct hydrogenation of HMF and the self-coupling of BAF. Consequently, the selectivity towards by-products BHF, BHTHF, and BAF-N-BAF are reduced. Same as above, the condensation of C=O in HMF with NH3 over the catalysts Co@SiO2–0.2 and Ni@SiO2–0.2 (Fig. 13B and 13D) initially leads to the formation of imine 1, which is hydrogenated to produce AMAF. Once the formation of AMAF, the furfuryl alcohol portion slowly undergoes dehydrogenation to generate AFCA. The generated AFCA rapidly condenses with NH3 to form imine 2, which is subsequently hydrogenated to produce BAF. Throughout this process, no BHF, BHTHF, and BAF-N-BAF were detected, because HMF completely condenses with ammonia on the acid sites of the SiO2 shell before diffusing into the metal core, and the pore volume of the SiO2 shell cannot accommodate two BAF molecules contacting each other, thus completely suppressing the direct hydrogenation of C=O and furan rings as well as the self-coupling of BAF, finally resulting in a further increase in BAF selectivity. For the Ni@SiO2–0.3 catalyst (Fig. 13E), due to the increase in the shell thickness, the small pore size and large channels of the SiO2 shell hinder the diffusion of HMF into and AMAF from the metal core, consequently slowing down the diffusion of AMAF with its hydroxyl towards the metal core and resulting in lower BAF selectivity. Thus, the core–shell structure catalysts exhibit contrasting kinetic properties compared to the impregnated catalysts and show distinct dynamic characteristics depending on the thickness of the SiO2 shell. 4 Conclusion A core–shell structured Ni@SiO2–0.2 catalyst for the one-step catalytically reductive amination of HMF to BAF has been developed. The catalyst demonstrated excellent performance in the reaction, and the yield of BAF reached up to 99 %, which is the best results up till now. The catalyst also showed excellent stability and can be recycled 7 times without obvious loss of its activity. The excellent performance of the Ni@SiO2–0.2 catalyst can be ascribed to the isolation effect of the SiO2 due to its suitable pore structure, selectively allowing reactants (HMF and AMAF) to diffuse to the Ni active centers, preventing direct hydrogenation reactions and self-coupling of BAF. The characterization results revealed that the Ni nanoparticles in the catalyst are uniformly dispersed and encapsulated within the SiO2 shell. The SiO2 shell reduces the binding energy of Ni, decreases the charge density on the Ni surface, and enhances the adsorption of ammonia and intermediates on the Ni surface, thus enhancing its catalytic activity. The porosity and pore size of the SiO2 shell can be tuned by adjusting the amount of TEOS during the preparation to optimize the performance of the catalyst. Besides, the appropriate acidity and acidic sites on the SiO2 shell facilitate the condensation of carbonyl with ammonia to imine, which is the reason to avoid direct hydrogenation of carbonyl to alcohol such as HMF to BHF. coredata.dc:description: 2,5-Bis(aminomethyl)furan (BAF) is a diamine that is expected to have extensive applications in organic synthesis, medicine and polymer materials such as polyamides and polyimides. BAF can be prepared by one-step reductive amination of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), one of the platform compounds for the added-valueconversion of biomass. Due to its complex structure, the one-step catalytically reductive amination of HMF to BAF in high yield is still a challenging issue. Herein, a core–shell structured catalyst (Ni@SiO2–0.2) was developed for this reaction, and the yield of BAF reached up to 99 % with aqueous ammonia as both ammonia source and solvent due to an isolation effect of the SiO2 shell. The isolation effect can prevent direct hydrogenation of HMF and self-coupling of BAF, thereby enhancing the selectivity of the reductive amination of HMF to BAF. In addition, the textural structure, acidity and acidic sites of the SiO2 shell can be tuned by adjusting the amount of TEOS during the catalyst preparation process, thus optimizing the performance of the catalyst. The characterization results also revealed that the Ni nanoparticles in the catalyst are uniformly dispersed and encapsulated within the SiO2 shell, which can decrease the charge density on the Ni surface and enhance the adsorption of ammonia and intermediates on the Ni surface, thus enhancing the catalytic activity of the catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: One-step reductive amination of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to 2,5-bis(aminomethyl)furan over a core–shell structured catalyst
